title: Most Common Verbs
text:
ser (to be)
Ser is one of the most important irregular verbs for beginning students. It is used in a vast number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations. Be careful when you need to choose between ser and estar. You should study the special rules for the use of estar. They’re listed with that verb.
Estar is one of the most important verbs for a beginning student to learn. In addition to the countless expressions that use estar, there is a distinction that you must make between estar and ser, which also means to be.
Tener is one of the most important irregular verbs for beginning students. It is used in a great number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations. Pay special attention to the stem changes!
Poder is a very useful verb for a beginning student. You can use it in a vast number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations.
Poder means can in the sense of ability:
In the preterit tense poder has the special meaning of succeeded:
Hacer is an essential irregular verb for beginning students of Spanish. It is used in many everyday situations and idiomatic expressions. Hacer is especially important for weather expressions
Ir and irse are a very important pair of verbs for a beginning student. In the following examples, note the difference in meaning between ir and the creflexive form irse.
Use ir when you simply mean to go:
Use irse when you mean to leave in the sense of to go away:

title: Disposition
text:
querer (to want)
Querer is a very important irregular verb for a beginning student. It is used in a great number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations.
Deber is a verb that you ought to know! It is a regular -er verb that is used in a great number of everyday expressions and situations.
Generally speaking, use deber when you want to express a moral obligation, something you ought to do, but that you may or may not actually do:
In general, deber de + inf. is used to express a supposition, something that is probable:

title: Cognition
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)

df = read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ghidinelli/fred-jehle-spanish-verbs/master/jehle_verb_database.csv")

my_gt_theme <- function(gt_object, ...) {
  
  stopifnot("'gt_object' must be a 'gt_tbl', have you accidentally passed raw data?" = "gt_tbl" %in% class(gt_object))
  
  tab_out <- gt_object %>%
    # Fonts
    opt_table_font(
      font = list(
        google_font("Noto Sans"), 
        google_font("Source Sans Pro"),
        default_fonts()
      )
    ) %>%
    
    # Cell styles from both themes
    tab_style(
      style = cell_borders(
        sides = "top", color = "white", weight = px(0)),
      locations = cells_body(rows = ifelse(nrow(gt_object[["_data"]]) > 0, 1, NA))) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(color = "#005689", size = px(22), weight = 700),
      locations = list(cells_title(groups = "title"))) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(color = "#545454", font = google_font("Source Sans Pro"), transform = "uppercase"),
      locations = cells_column_labels(everything())) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(font = google_font("Libre Franklin"), weight = 800),
      locations = cells_title(groups = "title")) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(font = google_font("Source Sans Pro"), weight = 400),
      locations = cells_body()) %>%
    
    # Table options combining elements of both themes
    tab_options(
      # Table-wide settings
      table.background.color = "white",
      table.font.size = 16,
      
      # Table border settings
      table.border.top.style = "none",
      table.border.top.width = px(1),
      table.border.top.color = "#40c5ff",
      table.border.bottom.width = px(3),
      table.border.bottom.color = "white",
      
      # Column label settings
      column_labels.background.color = "#f6f6f6",
      column_labels.font.weight = "bold",
      column_labels.border.top.style = "none",
      column_labels.border.bottom.style = "none",
      column_labels.border.bottom.width = 1,
      column_labels.border.bottom.color = "#334422",
      
      # Data row settings
      row.striping.include_table_body = TRUE,
      row.striping.background_color = "#ececec",
      data_row.padding = px(6), # Average of both themes
      
      # Row group settings
      row_group.font.weight = "800",
      
      # Heading settings
      heading.align = "left",
      heading.border.bottom.style = "none",
      
      # Table body border settings
      table_body.border.top.style = "none",
      
      # Source notes settings
      source_notes.font.size = 12,
      
    )
  
  return(tab_out)
}

create_conjugation_table <- function(verb_infinitive) {
  
  verb_order = c("Presente", 
                 "Imperfecto", 
                 "Pretérito", 
                 "Futuro", 
                 "Condicional", 
                 "Presente perfecto",
                 "Pluscuamperfecto",
                 "Pretérito anterior",
                 "Futuro perfecto",
                 "Condicional perfecto")
  
  verb_df <- df %>%
    filter(infinitive == verb_infinitive)
  
  infinitive = verb_df %>% pull(infinitive) %>% .[1] 
  english_infinitive = verb_df %>% pull(infinitive_english) %>% .[1] %>% str_to_title
  gerund = verb_df %>% pull(gerund) %>% .[1] 
  past_participle = verb_df %>% pull(pastparticiple) %>% .[1] 
  
  verb_table <- verb_df %>%
    select(-c(tense_english, 
              infinitive, 
              infinitive_english, 
              verb_english,
              # mood, 
              mood_english,
              gerund, 
              gerund_english, 
              pastparticiple, 
              pastparticiple_english
              )) %>%
    mutate(
      temp_form_2p = form_2p,
      form_2p = ifelse(mood %in% c("Imperativo Afirmativo","Imperativo Negativo"), form_3s, form_2p),
      form_3s = ifelse(mood %in% c("Imperativo Afirmativo","Imperativo Negativo"), temp_form_2p, form_3s),
      form_1p = ifelse(is.na(form_1p), paste0(form_3s, "mos"), form_1p),
      form_1s = ifelse(is.na(form_1s), " - ", form_1s)
    ) %>%
    select(-temp_form_2p) %>% 
    mutate(tense = factor(tense, levels = verb_order)) %>% 
    arrange(tense) %>% 
    group_by(mood) %>% 
    gt() %>%
    tab_header(
      title = paste("Conjugation of",infinitive),
      subtitle = md(glue::glue(sprintf("English: *{english_infinitive}*\n
                                     Gerundio: *{gerund}*\n
                                     Pasado Participio: *{past_participle}*")))) %>%
    cols_label(
      tense = "Tense",
      # verb_english = "English",
      form_1s = "Yo",
      form_2s = "Tú",
      form_3s = "Él/Ella/Usted",
      form_1p = "Nosotros",
      form_2p = "Vosotros",
      form_3p = "Ellos/Ellas/Ustedes"
    ) %>% 
    cols_align(
      align = c("right"),
      columns = everything()
    ) %>% 
    cols_align(
      align = c("left"),
      columns = tense
    ) %>% 
    my_gt_theme()

  return(verb_table)
}

#saber
Saber is a very useful irregular verb for you to know. It is used in a great number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations. Don’t confuse saber with conocer
Generally speaking, saber means to know a fact, to know something thoroughly:

¿Sabe Ud. qué hora es?/Do you know what time it is?
¿Sabe Ud. la lección?/Do you know the lesson?

When you use saber + inf., it means to know how:

¿Sabe Ud. nadar?/Do you know how to swim?
Sí, (yo) sé nadar/Yes, I know how to swim.

In the preterit tense, saber means to find out:

¿Lo sabe Ud.?/Do you know it?
Sí, lo supe ayer/Yes, I found it out yesterday.

#conocer
Conocer is a verb that you should know! Pay special attention to the spelling change from c to zc before a or o. Conocer is useful in numerous everyday expressions and situations
Be careful when choosing between conocer and saber, which also means to know.

(a) Generally speaking, conocer means to know in the sense of being acquainted with a person, a place, or a thing:

¿Conoce Ud. a María?
Do you know Mary?
¿Conoce Ud. bien los Estados Unidos?
Do you know the United States well?
¿Conoce Ud. este libro?
Do you know this book? (Are you acquainted with this book?)


In the preterit tense, conocer means met in the sense of first met, first became acquainted with someone: - ¿Conoce Ud. a Elena?
Do you know Helen? - Sí, (yo) la conocí anoche en casa de un amigo mío.
Yes, I met her (for the first time) last night at the home of one of my friends.
Generally speaking, saber means to know a fact, to know something thoroughly: - ¿Sabe Ud. qué hora es?
Do you know what time it is?
(See saber for further examples.)

title: 1  Level 1 verbs
text:
1.1 ser (to be)
Ser is one of the most important irregular verbs for beginning students. It is used in a vast number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations. Be careful when you need to choose between ser and estar. You should study the special rules for the use of estar. They’re listed with that verb.

1.1.2 Example Phrases

¿Qué hora es?

What time is it?

Es la una.

It’s one o’clock.

Son las dos

It’s two o’clock.

Será un regalo.

It will be a gift.

Para ser tan viejo, él es muy ágil.

In spite of being so old, he is very nimble.

Soy aficionado al béisbol.

I’m a baseball fan.

Mi profesora de español es amable conmigo.

My Spanish teacher is kind to me.

Te escucho. Soy de todo oídos.

I’m listening to you. I’m all ears.

Este libro es de María.

This book is Mary’s.




1.1.3 Proverbios

Dime con quién andas y te diré quién eres.

Tell me who your friends are and I will tell you who you are. (Birds of a feather flock together.)

text:
1.4 hacer (to do, to make)

1.4.1 Conjugation Table

title: Most Common Verbs
text:
Example Phrases

¿Qué hora es?

What time is it?

Es la una.

It’s one o’clock.

Son las dos

It’s two o’clock.

Será un regalo.

It will be a gift.

Para ser tan viejo, él es muy ágil.

In spite of being so old, he is very nimble.

Soy aficionado al béisbol.

I’m a baseball fan.

Mi profesora de español es amable conmigo.

My Spanish teacher is kind to me.

Te escucho. Soy de todo oídos.

I’m listening to you. I’m all ears.

Este libro es de María.

This book is Mary’s.

title: Most Common Verbs
section: When to use estar vs ser
text:
When to use estar vs ser
Health:

¿Cómo está Ud.? How are you?
Estoy bien. I am well.
Estoy enfermo (enferma). I am sick.

Location: persons, places, things

Estoy en la sala de clase. I am in the classroom.
La escuela está lejos. The school is far.
Barcelona está en España. Barcelona is (located) in Spain.
Los libros están en la mesa. The books are on the table.

State or condition: persons

Estoy contento (contenta). I am happy.
Los alumnos están cansados. (Las alumnas están cansadas.) The students are tired.
María está triste hoy. Mary is sad today.
Estoy listo (lista). I am ready.
Estoy pálido (pálida). I am pale.
Estoy ocupado (ocupada). I am busy.
Estoy seguro (segura). I am sure.
Este hombre está vivo. This man is alive.
Ese hombre está muerto. That man is dead.
Este hombre está borracho. This man is drunk.

To form the progressive present of a verb:
use the present tense of estar + the present participle of the main verb

Estoy estudiando en mi cuarto y no puedo salir esta noche.

I am studying in my room and I cannot go out tonight.


To form the progressive past of a verb:
use the imperfect tense of estar + the present participle of the main verb:

Mi hermano estaba leyendo cuando (yo) entré en el cuarto.

My brother was reading when I entered (came into) the room.

title: Level 1 verbs
text:
Expressions and Formulas

¿Cuánto tiempo hace que + present tense…?

Use this formula when you want to ask “How long + the present perfect tense” in English.

¿Cuánto tiempo hace que Ud. estudia español?

How long have you been studying Spanish?



¿Hace + length of time + que + present tense

This formula is the usual answer to the question “¿Cuánto tiempo hace que + present tense…?”

Hace tres años que estudio español.

I have been studying Spanish for three years.



¿Desde cuándo + present tense…?

¿Desde cuándo estudia Ud. español?

How long have you been studying Spanish?


Present tense + desde hace + length of time

Estudio español desde hace tres años.

I have been studying Spanish for three years.


¿Cuánto tiempo hacía que + imperfect tense?

This formula is equivalent to the English “How long + past perfect tense”.

¿Cuánto tiempo hacía que Ud. hablaba cuando entré en la sala de clase?

How long had you been talking when I entered the classroom?



Hacía + length of time + que + imperfect tense

Hacía una hora que yo hablaba cuando Ud. entró en la sala de clase.

I had been talking for one hour when you entered the classroom.


¿Desde cuándo + imperfect tense…?

¿Desde cuándo hablaba Ud. cuando yo entré en la sala de clase?

How long had you been talking when I entered the classroom?


Imperfect tense + desde hacía + length of time

(Yo) hablaba desde hacía una hora cuando Ud. entró en la sala de clase.

I had been talking for one hour when you entered the classroom.

title: Most Common Verbs
text:
Formulas with hacer
¿Cuánto tiempo hace que + present tense…?

Use this formula when you want to ask How long + the present perfect tense in English:

¿Cuánto tiempo hace que Ud. estudia español?

How long have you been studying Spanish?


When this formula is used, you generally expect the person to tell you how long a time it has been, e.g., one year, two months, a few minutes.

This is used when the action began at some time in the past and continues up to the present moment. That is why you must use the present tense of the verb—the action of studying, waiting, etc., is still going on at the present.

¿Hace + length of time + que + present tense

This formula is the usual answer to the question ¿Cuánto tiempo hace que + present tense…?

Since the question is asked in terms of how long, the usual answer is in terms of time: a year, two years, a few days, months, minutes, etc.:

Hace tres años que estudio español.

I have been studying Spanish for three years.


The same formula is used if you want to ask how many weeks, how many months, how many minutes, etc.:

¿Cuántos años hace que Ud. estudia español?

How many years have you been studying Spanish?


¿Desde cuándo + present tense…?
- ¿Desde cuándo estudia Ud. español?
- How long have you been studying Spanish?
Present tense + desde hace + length of time
- Estudio español desde hace tres años.
- I have been studying Spanish for three years.

Queremos alquilar un coche, por favor.

Te quiero.

I love you.

El que todo lo quiere, todo lo pierde.

Whoever wants everything loses everything.

title: Disposition
text:
Example Phrases

José debe de haber llegado.

Joseph must have arrived.

¿Cuánto le debo?

How much do I owe you?

¿En qué estación debo bajar?

At what station do I need to get off?

Es muy tarde, debería regresar a casa.

It’s very late, I ought to return home.








Note



Generally speaking, use tener que when you want to say that you have to do something:

No puedo salir esta noche porque tengo que estudiar.

I cannot go out tonight because I have to study.

See tener.

title: Movement B
text:
Code
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)

df = read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/ghidinelli/fred-jehle-spanish-verbs/master/jehle_verb_database.csv")

my_gt_theme <- function(gt_object, ...) {
  
  stopifnot("'gt_object' must be a 'gt_tbl', have you accidentally passed raw data?" = "gt_tbl" %in% class(gt_object))
  
  tab_out <- gt_object %>%
    # Fonts
    opt_table_font(
      font = list(
        google_font("Noto Sans"), 
        google_font("Source Sans Pro"),
        default_fonts()
      )
    ) %>%
    
    # Cell styles from both themes
    tab_style(
      style = cell_borders(
        sides = "top", color = "white", weight = px(0)),
      locations = cells_body(rows = ifelse(nrow(gt_object[["_data"]]) > 0, 1, NA))) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(color = "#005689", size = px(22), weight = 700),
      locations = list(cells_title(groups = "title"))) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(color = "#545454", font = google_font("Source Sans Pro"), transform = "uppercase"),
      locations = cells_column_labels(everything())) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(font = google_font("Libre Franklin"), weight = 800),
      locations = cells_title(groups = "title")) %>%
    tab_style(
      style = cell_text(font = google_font("Source Sans Pro"), weight = 400),
      locations = cells_body()) %>%
    
    # Table options combining elements of both themes
    tab_options(
      # Table-wide settings
      table.background.color = "white",
      table.font.size = 16,
      
      # Table border settings
      table.border.top.style = "none",
      table.border.top.width = px(1),
      table.border.top.color = "#40c5ff",
      table.border.bottom.width = px(3),
      table.border.bottom.color = "white",
      
      # Column label settings
      column_labels.background.color = "#f6f6f6",
      column_labels.font.weight = "bold",
      column_labels.border.top.style = "none",
      column_labels.border.bottom.style = "none",
      column_labels.border.bottom.width = 1,
      column_labels.border.bottom.color = "#334422",
      
      # Data row settings
      row.striping.include_table_body = TRUE,
      row.striping.background_color = "#ececec",
      data_row.padding = px(6), # Average of both themes
      
      # Row group settings
      row_group.font.weight = "800",
      
      # Heading settings
      heading.align = "left",
      heading.border.bottom.style = "none",
      
      # Table body border settings
      table_body.border.top.style = "none",
      
      # Source notes settings
      source_notes.font.size = 12,
      
    )
  
  return(tab_out)
}

create_conjugation_table <- function(verb_infinitive) {
  
  verb_order = c("Presente", 
                 "Imperfecto", 
                 "Pretérito", 
                 "Futuro", 
                 "Condicional", 
                 "Presente perfecto",
                 "Pluscuamperfecto",
                 "Pretérito anterior",
                 "Futuro perfecto",
                 "Condicional perfecto")
  
  verb_df <- df %>%
    filter(infinitive == verb_infinitive)
  
  infinitive = verb_df %>% pull(infinitive) %>% .[1] 
  english_infinitive = verb_df %>% pull(infinitive_english) %>% .[1] %>% str_to_title
  gerund = verb_df %>% pull(gerund) %>% .[1] 
  past_participle = verb_df %>% pull(pastparticiple) %>% .[1] 
  
  verb_table <- verb_df %>%
    select(-c(tense_english, 
              infinitive, 
              infinitive_english, 
              verb_english,
              # mood, 
              mood_english,
              gerund, 
              gerund_english, 
              pastparticiple, 
              pastparticiple_english
              )) %>%
    mutate(
      temp_form_2p = form_2p,
      form_2p = ifelse(mood %in% c("Imperativo Afirmativo","Imperativo Negativo"), form_3s, form_2p),
      form_3s = ifelse(mood %in% c("Imperativo Afirmativo","Imperativo Negativo"), temp_form_2p, form_3s),
      form_1p = ifelse(is.na(form_1p), paste0(form_3s, "mos"), form_1p),
      form_1s = ifelse(is.na(form_1s), " - ", form_1s)
    ) %>%
    select(-temp_form_2p) %>% 
    mutate(tense = factor(tense, levels = verb_order)) %>% 
    arrange(tense) %>% 
    group_by(mood) %>% 
    gt() %>%
    tab_header(
      title = paste("Conjugation of",infinitive),
      subtitle = md(glue::glue(sprintf("English: *{english_infinitive}*\n
                                     Gerundio: *{gerund}*\n
                                     Pasado Participio: *{past_participle}*")))) %>%
    cols_label(
      tense = "Tense",
      # verb_english = "English",
      form_1s = "Yo",
      form_2s = "Tú",
      form_3s = "Él/Ella/Usted",
      form_1p = "Nosotros",
      form_2p = "Vosotros",
      form_3p = "Ellos/Ellas/Ustedes"
    ) %>% 
    cols_align(
      align = c("right"),
      columns = everything()
    ) %>% 
    cols_align(
      align = c("left"),
      columns = tense
    ) %>% 
    my_gt_theme()

  return(verb_table)
}

title: Learning
text:
Proverb

Después de comer, ni un sobre escrito leer.

After eating, don’t even read an envelope.

title: Learning
text:
Example Phrases

dar a entender

to insinuate, to hint

Yo me entiendo.

I have my reasons.

según mi entender

according to my opinion

el entendimiento

comprehension, understanding

¿Qué entiende Ud. por eso?

What do you mean by that?

entenderse bien

to get along well with each other

desentenderse de

to have nothing to do with

title: Learning
text:
Example Phrases

En la clase de español estamos aprendiendo a hablar, a leer, y a escribir en español.

In Spanish class we are learning to speak, to read, and to write in Spanish.

Machacando se aprende el oficio.

Practice makes perfect.

Mi abuela aprendió a navegar en Internet.

My grandmother learned to surf the Internet.

Estoy aprendiendo el diseño web para ser administrador de web.

I am learning web design to become a webmaster.

title: Learning
text:
Proverbs

El que mucho duerme poco aprende.

Whoever sleeps a lot learns little.

Cada día se aprende algo nuevo.

You learn something new every day.

title: Learning
text:
Dichos

el aprendizaje

apprenticeship

el aprendizaje en línea

online learning, e-learning

el aprendiz, la aprendiza

apprentice

aprender a + inf.

to learn + inf.

aprender de memoria

to memorize

aprender con

to study with

desaprender

to unlearn

aprendiz de todo (mucho), oficial de nada

Jack of all trades, master of none

title: Learning
text:
Example Phrases

Dígame, por favor, dónde está la sala de espera.

Tell me, please, where the waiting room is located.

¿Qué quiere decir esta palabra?

What does this word mean?
¡Te he dicho mil veces de ponerte el cinturón de seguridad!
I’ve told you a thousand times to put on your seat belt!

Proverbios

Dime con quién andas y te diré quién eres.
Tell me who your friends are and I will tell you who you are.

Al decir las verdades se pierdan las amistades.

Friendships are lost when the truth is told.

De decir a hacer hay mucho que ver.

There is a great difference between saying and doing.

title: Learning
text:
Dichos

Dicho y hecho.

No sooner said than done.

querer decir

to mean

un decir

a familiar saying

Diga or Dígame

Hello (on the telephone)

decirle al oído

to whisper in one’s ear

no decir palabra

not to say a word

Es decir…

That is to say…

un dicho

a saying, expression

dictar

to dictate

el dictado

dictation

el dictador

dictator

decir mentiras

to tell lies

decir adiós

to say good-bye

bendecir

to bless

maldecir

to curse, to swear

title: Learning
text:
Example Phrases

Aquí se habla español.

Spanish is spoken here.

No me gusta hablar a gritos.

I don’t like to shout.

Antes de hablar es bueno pensar.

(It’s good to) think before you speak.

El dinero habla.

Money talks.

Hable más despacio, por favor.

Speak more slowly, please.

—¿Me podría poner con la Señora Del Toro, por favor? —Ella habla.

—Could you please put me through to Mrs. Del Toro? —Speaking.

title: Learning
text:
Proverbio

Para saber hablar, hay que saber escuchar.

In order to know how to talk, one must know how to listen.

title: Learning
text:
Dichos

la habladuría

gossip, idle rumor

hispanohablante

Spanish-speaking

de habla española

Spanish-speaking

de habla inglesa

English-speaking

hablador, habladora

talkative

hablar a gritos

to shout

hablar entre dientes

to mumble

hablar al oído

to whisper in someone’s ear

hablar de

to talk about

hablar en voz baja

to speak softly

title: Learning
text:
Example Phrases

—¿Cómo se llama usted? —Me llamo Juan Morales. —¿Y cómo se llaman sus hermanos? —Se llaman Teresa y Pedro.

—What is your name? (How do you call yourself?) —My name is Juan Morales. —And what are your siblings’ names? —Their names are Teresa and Peter.

¿Puede llamar a un médico, por favor?

Can you call a doctor, please?

Llámame.

Call me. (Give me a call.)

text:

llamar por los nombres

to call the roll

to call a taxi

una llamada

call, knock, ring

hacer una llamada telefónica

to make a phone call

un llamador, una llamadora

caller

Mi nombre es…

My name is…

llamado, llamada

called, named, so-called

text:
Example Phrases

El comedor da al jardín.

The dining room faces the garden.

Esta mañana di con dinero en la calle.

This morning, I found money in the street.

Anoche, di con mi amiga Elena en el cine.

Last night, I met my friend Helen at the movies.

El tiempo da buen consejo.

Time will tell.

Dame dineros y no consejos.

Give me money, and not advice.

Me gusta dar de comer a los pájaros en el parque.

I like to feed the birds in the park.

Lo doy por perdido.

I consider it lost.

Me doy por insultado.

I consider myself insulted.

title: Most Common Verbs
text:
to be
Ser is one of the most important irregular verbs for beginning students. It is used in a vast number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations. Be careful when you need to choose between ser and estar. You should study the special rules for the use of estar. They’re listed with that verb.

title: Most Common Verbs
text:
to be
Estar is one of the most important verbs for a beginning student to learn. In addition to the countless expressions that use estar, there is a distinction that you must make between estar and ser, which also means to be.

title: Most Common Verbs
text:
can, to be able to
Poder is a very useful verb for a beginning student. You can use it in a vast number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations.
Poder means can in the sense of ability:

No puedo ayudarle; lo siento

I cannot (am unable to) help you; I’m sorry.


In the preterit tense poder has the special meaning of succeeded:

Después de algunos minutos, Juan pudo abrir la puerta

After a few minutes, John succeeded in opening the door.

title: Most Common Verbs
text:
to do, to make
Hacer is an essential irregular verb for beginning students of Spanish. It is used in many everyday situations and idiomatic expressions. Hacer is especially important for weather expressions

title: Most Common Verbs
text:
to go
Ir and irse are a very important pair of verbs for a beginning student. In the following examples, note the difference in meaning between ir and the creflexive form irse.
Use ir when you simply mean to go:

Voy al cine

I am going to the movies.


Use irse when you mean to leave in the sense of to go away:

Mis padres se fueron al campo para visitar a mis abuelos

My parents left for (went away to) the country to visit my grandparents.

title: Most Common Verbs
text:
to have
Tener is one of the most important irregular verbs for beginning students. It is used in a great number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations. Pay special attention to the stem changes!

title: Disposition
text:
to want
Querer is a very important irregular verb for a beginning student. It is used in a great number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations.

title: Disposition
text:
to owe, must, ought
Deber is a verb that you ought to know! It is a regular -er verb that is used in a great number of everyday expressions and situations.
Generally speaking, use deber when you want to express a moral obligation, something you ought to do, but that you may or may not actually do:

Debo estudiar esta noche pero estoy cansado y no me siento bien.

I ought to study tonight, but I am tired and I do not feel well.


In general, deber de + inf. is used to express a supposition, something that is probable:

La señora Gómez debe de estar enferma porque sale de casa raramente.

Mrs. Gómez must be sick (is probably sick) because she rarely goes out of the house

Gustar is an essential regular -ar verb for beginning students of Spanish. It is used in many everyday expressions and situations. Please note that this verb is commonly used in the third person singular or plural, as in the examples below.

(a) Essentially, the verb gustar means to be pleasing to…
(b) In English, we say, for example, I like ice cream. In Spanish, we say Me gusta el helado; that is to say, “Ice cream is pleasing to me (Literally: To me, ice cream is pleasing).”
(c) In English, the thing that you like is the direct object. In Spanish, the thing that you like is the subject. Also, in Spanish, the person who likes the thing is the indirect object: to me, to you, etc. For example: “A Roberto le gusta el helado/Robert likes ice cream (Literally: To Robert, ice cream is pleasing to him).”
(d) In Spanish, therefore, the verb gustar is used in the third person, either in the singular or plural, when you talk about something that you like— something that is pleasing to you. Therefore, the verb form must agree with the subject; if the thing that is liked is singular, the verb is third person singular: Me gusta el café/I like coffee. If the thing that is liked is plural, the verb gustar is third person plural: “Me gustan el café y la leche/I like coffee and milk (Literally: Coffee and milk are pleasing to me).”
(e) When you mention the person or the persons who like something, you must use the preposition a in front of the person. You must also use the indirect object pronoun that is associated with the person: A los muchachos y a las muchachas les gusta jugar/Boys and girls like to play. (Literally: To boys and girls, to play is pleasing to them.)

title: Cognition
text:
to think
We think that pensar is a very useful verb for you to learn. It is used in a great number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations. Pay attention to the stem change in Tenses 1 and 6 and in the imperative mood.
Pensar is used with the preposition de when you ask someone what he/she thinks of someone or something, i.e., when you ask for someone’s opinion:

¿Qué piensa Ud. de este libro?

What do you think of this book?

Pienso que es bueno

I think that it is good.


Pensar is used with the preposition en when you ask someone what or whom he/she is thinking about:

Miguel, no hablas mucho; ¿en qué piensas?

Michael, you are not talking much; what are you thinking of? (of what are you thinking?);

Pienso en las vacaciones de verano

I’m thinking of summer vacation.

title: Cognition

to believe
We believe that creer is a useful verb for you to learn because it has an important stem change in Tenses 3 and 7. This verb is helpful in a great number of everyday expressions and situations.

title: Cognition
text:
to know, to know how
Saber is a very useful irregular verb for you to know. It is used in a great number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations. Don’t confuse saber with conocer
Generally speaking, saber means to know a fact, to know something thoroughly:

¿Sabe Ud. qué hora es?/Do you know what time it is?
¿Sabe Ud. la lección?/Do you know the lesson?

When you use saber + inf., it means to know how:

¿Sabe Ud. nadar?/Do you know how to swim?
Sí, (yo) sé nadar/Yes, I know how to swim.

In the preterit tense, saber means to find out:

¿Lo sabe Ud.?/Do you know it?
Sí, lo supe ayer/Yes, I found it out yesterday.

¿Cómo andan los negocios?

How’s business?

Anda despacio que tengo prisa.

Make haste slowly.

Amadís de Gaula fue un caballero andante de la Edad Media.

Amadis of Gaul was a knight-errant of the Middle Ages.

¡Anda a pasear!

Take a walk! (Take a hike!)

¡A Magdalena le gusta andar a caballo! Anda a caballo tres veces por semana.

Madeleine loves horseback riding! She rides a horse three times a week.

Dime con quién andas y te diré quién eres.

Tell me who your friends are and I will tell you who you are.

Poco a poco se anda lejos.

One step at a time. (Little by little, one goes far away.)

title: Movement A
text:
to go out, to leave
Salir is a very useful irregular verb for you to learn. It is used in a great number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations.
Be careful not to confuse salir and dejar. Use salir de when you mean to leave in the sense of to go out of (a place): > El alumno salió de la sala de clase.
> The pupil left the classroom.

The Spanish Idiomatic Expression
acabar de + inf. in Spanish is translated to English as to have just + past participle.

Present Indicative:
When you use acabar in the present tense, it indicates that the action of the main verb (+ inf.) has just occurred now in the present. In English, we express this using have just + the past participle of the main verb.
Examples:

María acaba de llegar.

Mary has just arrived.

Acabo de comer.

I have just eaten.

Acabamos de terminar la lección.

We have just finished the lesson.




Imperfect Indicative:
When using acabar in the imperfect indicative, it denotes that the action of the main verb (+ inf.) had occurred at some past time when another action transpired. In English, this is articulated using had just + the past participle of the main verb.
Examples:

María acababa de llegar.

Mary had just arrived.

Yo acababa de comer.

I had just eaten.

Acabábamos de terminar la lección.

We had just finished the lesson.

title: Movement B
text:
Proverbio

Bien está lo que bien acaba.

All’s well that ends well.

title: Movement B
text:

to end in

acabar por

to end by, to … finally

acabado, acabada

finished








Note




Note: When acabar is used in the imperfect indicative + inf. (of the main verb being expressed), the verb in the other clause is typically in the preterit.
Example:
Acabábamos de entrar cuando el teléfono sonó.
We had just entered the house when the telephone rang.

title: Movement B
section: to begin, to start, to commence
text:
to begin, to start, to commence
Comenzar is a useful verb for beginning Spanish students because it has an important stem change and a spelling change from z to c before the letter e. It is also used in numerous everyday expressions and situations.

title: Movement B
text:
Example Phrases

–¿Qué tiempo hace?

—What is the weather like?

–Comienza a llover.

—It’s starting to rain.

–Quiero comenzar al comienzo.

—I’d like to begin at the beginning.

–¡Comienza!

—Begin!

title: Movement B
text:
Proverb

Lo que mal comienza, mal acaba.

What starts badly ends badly.

title: Movement B
text:
Dichos

el comienzo

the beginning

Note: la ceremonia de graduación (school)

commencement

al comienzo

at the beginning, at first

comenzar a + inf.

to begin + inf.

comenzar por + inf.

to begin by + pres. part.

comenzar por el principio

to begin at the beginning

recomenzar

to begin again

title: Movement B
section: to carry (away), to take (away), to wear
text:
to carry (away), to take (away), to wear
Llevar is an essential regular -ar verb for beginning students of Spanish. It is used in many idiomatic expressions and everyday situations.
Llevar generally translates to “to take” in English, especially in the context of carrying or transporting items from one place to another.

Example:
José llevó la silla de la cocina al comedor.
Joseph took the chair from the kitchen to the dining room.

Moreover, llevar is used when indicating taking someone to a place.

Example:
Pedro llevó a María al baile anoche.
Peter took Mary to the dance last night.

Additionally, llevar can mean “to wear”.

Example:
María, ¿por qué llevas la falda nueva?
Mary, why are you wearing your new skirt?

title: Movement B

I’ll take it with me.

Aquel hombre lleva una vida de perros.

That man leads a dog’s life.

Traer is a very useful irregular verb for beginning students. It is used in a great number of idiomatic expressions and everyday situations. Pay special attention to the stem changes!

Tráigame una silla, por favor.

Bring me a chair, please.

¿Qué te trae por aquí?

What brings you here?

¿Quién trajo el pastel?

Who brought the cake?

Yo lo traje.

Caer and caerse are an important pair of verbs for a beginning student. Both verbs are irregular and they are very useful in many everyday situations and expressions. Pay special attention when you use caer reflexively (caerse).

title: Movement B
text:
Example Phrases

Mi madre cayó enferma en octubre.

My mother fell ill in October.

Yo me caí por la ventana. Por suerte, estuve en la planta baja.

I fell out of the window. Luckily, I was on the first floor.

El hombre que se levanta aún es más grande que el que no ha caído. (Concepción Arenal)

The man who gets up is even greater than the one who hasn’t fallen.

title: Movement B
text:
Proverb

Caen las hojas y caerán los árboles.

All in good time. (Lit.: Leaves fall and trees will fall.)

Cantar is a very important regular -ar verb that is used in numerous everyday expressions and situations.

text:

Fuimos a una ópera en el Palacio de Bellas Artes. La cantante era estupenda y cantó maravillosamente.

We went to an opera at the Palace of Fine Arts. The opera singer was marvelous and she sang wonderfully.

title: Life
text:

Quien canta su mal espanta.

When you sing, you drive away your grief.

El que mal canta, bien le suena.

One can never get back lost time.

What is lost today is won tomorrow.

title: Most Common Verbs
section: to have (as an auxiliary, helping verb to form the compound tenses)
text:
to have (as an auxiliary, helping verb to form the compound tenses)
Haber is an essential verb for beginning students of Spanish. You need to be able to conjugate haber in order to form the compound tenses. In other words, if you can conjugate haber in the simple tenses, you can form any other verb in the compound tenses! The verb haber is used as an auxiliary (helping) verb as follows:
